main_forecast:
SwellCaldWell Outlook
| Day/Window           | Direction (deg/cardinal) | Period (s) | H1/3 (ft) | H1/10 est (ft) | Trend                    | Notes |
|---|---|---:|---:|---:|---|---|
| Thu 10/16            | NNW–NW (300–340)         | 13–15      | 3–4       | 5–6            | Steady                    | Post-frontal mid-period mix; modest N windswell component. Watch 51101/51001. |
| Fri 10/17            | NNW–NW (305–330)         | 12–14      | 3–5       | 5–7            | Steady to slight bump     | Reinforcing mid-period NNW. 51101 should hold; 51001 leads. |
| Sat 10/18 (PM rise)  | NW (310–330)              | 17–18      | 2 → 4–6 late | 3–4 → 6–8+   | Rising late afternoon/eve | Long-period Gulf forerunners. Deepwater 5@18s ETA ~5:30 PM HST; sets jump near/after dusk. |
| Thu–Sat              | ENE Trades (70–90)        | 7–9        | 2–4 (windward) | 4–5        | Steady                    | Trade-wind short-period surf for E exposures. Check 51003/51004. |
| Thu–Sat              | S–SSW (190–210)           | 12–14      | 1–2       | 2–3            | Fading/flat               | Background only. SW 214° 13s spike in matrix likely a buoy partition artifact; negligible surf. |

SUMMARY
- Dominant feature: a long-period NW (310–330°) swell from a 971 mb Gulf low, forerunners due Saturday afternoon with a sharper rise near/after sunset; peak likely Sunday outside this window.
- Until then, small-moderate, mid-period NNW–NW keeps the North Shore active Thursday–Friday.
- Winds: E–ENE trades light to moderate (PHNL 070°/8 kt late Wed). Typical lighter AMs, breezier PMs. Forecast confidence: medium (0.68). Models/altimetry feeds are missing; leaning on buoy snapshots and charts.

DETAILS
- Long-period NW event (Gulf of Alaska):
  - Source: ~50N 148W, 971 mb storm, ENE ~20 kt with storm-force backside fetch aimed 310–340° toward HI. OPC shows 8–10+ m source seas.
  - Physics-based arrival: deepwater 5 ft @ 18 s Saturday ~5:32 PM HST (distance ~1800 nm; 2.7 days). Expect 20 s scouts mid/late afternoon, 18 s filling evening. Nearshore H1/3 builds from 2–3 ft midday to 4–6 ft late, with H1/10 sets to 6–8+ ft faces at focal reefs by dusk/night.
  - Buoys: 51001 (far NE Pac) should show the bulk long before Oahu; 51101 (NW of Kauai) is the key trigger for Oahu timing of the 18–20 s band.
- Mid-period NNW–NW mix (holding Thu–Fri):
  - Drivers: post-frontal gale ~44N 170W and a frontal wave near 31N 165W keeping 12–15 s energy in the 300–340° sector.
  - Nearshore: H1/3 3–4 ft Thu, 3–5 ft Fri, H1/10 sets 5–7 ft faces on best exposures. Some shorter-period N windswell blends in.
  - Buoys: 51101/nearby arrays should hold mid-period energy; check for subtle reinforcement Friday.
- Trades/short-period ENE:
  - Ridge 1031–1032 mb near 33N 145–150W maintains E–ENE trades. Windward surf 2–4 ft H1/3, 7–9 s. Buoys 51003/51004 supportive.
- South exposures:
  - No South Pacific source recently; CPC tropical outlook quiet for 7 days. The matrix’s SW 214° 16 ft @ 13 s print is inconsistent with season/pattern and likely a partition artifact; expect 1–2 ft H1/3, inconsistent.

NORTH SHORE
- Thu (10/16): NNW–NW 13–15 s. H1/3 3–4 ft; H1/10 sets near 5–6 ft faces at top exposures. Light E flow early; moderate trades PM. Fair conditions at many reefs with side/offshore bias.
- Fri (10/17): Similar or a notch up. H1/3 3–5 ft; sets 5–7 ft faces. Mixed periods keep consistency decent. Manageable winds.
- Sat (10/18): AM modest 3–4 ft. Forerunners 18–20 s by afternoon; sharper rise late to H1/3 4–6 ft with H1/10 6–8+ ft faces at Sunset/Waimea/Pipeline by dusk and into the night. E–ENE trades are side/offshore; expect stronger currents with the rising long-period energy.
- Notes: Use 51001 for early heads-up and 51101 for imminent arrival. Timing/size carries medium confidence given missing model/altimetry feeds; adjust with buoy trends.

SOUTH SHORE
- Thu–Sat: Background S–SSW 12–14 s only. H1/3 1–2 ft; H1/10 2–3 ft faces on the better magnets. Trades are side/offshore; mornings cleanest. A whisper of N wrap possible Saturday evening on select southern exposures as NW energy noses in, but minimal.

EAST (WINDWARD)
- Thu–Sat: Trade swell steady at H1/3 2–4 ft (7–9 s), choppy PM with trades, cleaner AMs. Northern Windward exposures may see extra NNW wrap Fri–Sat pushing sets to 3–5 ft faces at times.

OUTLOOK
- Sun (10/19): The NW long-period swell should be the main event. H1/3 5–8 ft on the North Shore with H1/10 sets 8–12 ft faces at focal reefs; still building early, leveling/peaking through the day. Trades moderate E–ENE.
- Mon (10/20): Gradual easing but still solid: H1/3 4–6 ft; H1/10 6–9 ft faces. Windward steady 2–4 ft trades. South shore remains near-flat.
- Next potential: A pre-dateline gale near 35–40N, 170E–180 bears watching. If it reorients toward 170W with a meridional fetch, a conditional WNW (290–310°) pulse could follow mid-next week. Low confidence at this lead.

Data/Confidence notes
- Confidence medium (0.68). Altimetry, models, nearshore buoy feeds missing; relied on surface charts, CPC outlook, and available NDBC buoys (51101/51001 for NW, 51003/51004 for trades). The SW 214° 13 s “16 ft” buoy line is discounted as spurious given regional pattern and lack of South Pacific support.
north_shore:
Lead: A very large, long-period NNW swell (330° ±10°) dominates Thu–Fri, with deep-water H1/3 near 15–16 ft and H1/10 near 20 ft on the buoys (exposure weight ~0.93 for open North Shore), translating to roughly 20–30 ft faces with occasional 30–40 ft sets at the most exposed reefs, peaking overnight Wed–Thu, holding through Thu, and easing Fri; forerunners of the next NW pulse (about 5 ft @ 18 s from the Gulf of Alaska) are due late Sat toward dusk.

Wind and tides: Light to moderate ENE trades early (around 070° at 5–10 kt per METAR), trending E 10–15+ kt each afternoon, gives the classic morning window: cleaner and a bit offshore for Pipe/Backdoor, more cross for Sunset, and manageable at Waimea. Afternoon onshores add bump and warble, most noticeable at wide-open exposures. Predawn lower tides with higher afternoon tides through the period favor tubes at lower water on the reefs early; the higher afternoon tide helps Waimea smooth out but can increase surges near harbor mouths. Note: local tide precision is limited from the feed; lean on on-site checks for session timing.

Flagship breaks:
- Pipeline/Backdoor (exposure strong to 330° NNW): Thu very solid 15–20 ft faces with second-reef sets 20–25+ and intermittent first-reef closeouts; Fri easing to 10–15 ft, still powerful; Sat morning down to 6–10 ft, with a slight tick up late day as 18 s forerunners sneak in near dusk. Best quality early with light ENE; afternoons trend side/onshore and lumpy.
- Sunset Beach (max exposure; weight ~0.93): Thu XL 20–30 ft faces with occasional 30–35+ bombs; strong currents and wide playing field; Fri 12–18 ft, easing; Sat 8–12 ft AM, holding or bumping late PM on forerunners. Mornings fair; afternoons bumpy with trades.
- Waimea Bay (likes N–NW long period): Thu 18–25 ft faces with sets pushing 30 ft during peak; Fri 12–18 ft; Sat 8–12 ft with late-day pulses possible. Higher tide helps the roll-ins; currents and surges significant even as it drops.

Buoy evidence and exposure notes:
- Primary energy is the NNW 15–16 ft @ 15 s cluster from ~329–343° with strong North Shore exposure (weights ~0.93 for NNW, ~0.82 for NW). This aligns with the observed jump on the buoys and supports warning-level surf at the most open reefs.
- Secondary NW/WNW components (13 ft @ 13 s from ~300–310° and ~7 ft @ 13 s WNW) add cross energy but are a sideshow to the dominant NNW. Pipeline is partially shadowed from WNW, but the NNW angle opens it up and can make the first reef unruly at peak size.
- Large SW (214°) energy on the buoys is heavily shadowed for the North Shore and is not a meaningful contributor here.

Hazards: Expect high to warning-level surf on Thu for north exposures. Very strong rip and longshore currents, powerful shorebreak in exposed pockets, outer-reef wash-throughs, and harbor surges (e.g., Haleiwa) are likely during the peak. Only expert-level big-wave equipment and teams should consider outer reefs and Waimea during the max.

Outlook and timing:
- Thu (10/16): Peak of the event overnight into morning; holds high through the day; gradually trends down late.
- Fri (10/17): Slow easer all day, still sizable and powerful at top exposures.
- Sat (10/18): Down another notch for most of the day; long-period NW forerunners (5 ft @ 18 s; travel time ~2.7 days from the Gulf of Alaska source) slated to arrive near/after sunset, with more material likely overnight into Sunday.

Confidence: Moderate (0.68). Strength-of-signal is solid on regional buoys for the NNW event, and climatology favors early-season NNW pulses. However, several feeds are missing (models, altimetry, nearshore buoys, satellite, upper-air), so decay rates and the exact onset of the Sat forerunners could be off by 6–12 hours, and nearshore transformation details carry more uncertainty than usual.
south_shore:
South Shore forecast (Thu 10/16 – Sat 10/18), in brief
- Size/period/direction: Background S–SSW pulses in the 12–14s band dominate; trace NW/WNW wrap rides shotgun. No true southern-hemisphere storm signal on the charts.
- Nearshore breakers (faces): 
  • Thu: H1/3 2 ft, H1/10 3 ft from 190–205°. Trace W–NW wrap <1 ft. 
  • Fri: H1/3 1.5–2 ft, H1/10 2.5–3 ft from 190–205°. Trace W–NW wrap <1 ft. 
  • Sat: H1/3 1.5–2 ft, H1/10 2.5–3 ft from 185–200°. Late-day, rare knee-thigh pulses from first-arriving NNW 18s wrap at select magnets.
- Timing: Most consistency on the tide push late morning to midday; smallest overnight and late afternoon lows. Morning winds are lightest; trades build and texture the bump by late morning onward.

What’s driving it
- Background southern hemi: Lingering S–SSW swell energy in the 12–14s band keeps Town rideable but small through Saturday. This is classic October—end of season background, not a storm-fed run.
- Wrap potential: Large NNW–NW energy in the basin is well sampled on buoys but is heavily blocked for Town. Expect only a whisper of wrap through the deep channels for west-facing nooks (Rockpiles/Kaisers zone) Thursday–Friday. A new, long-period NNW pulse (~5 ft @ 18s deepwater) is modeled to reach the islands late Saturday; that will barely tickle wrap magnets near sunset with very inconsistent knee-thigh lines. For most south-facing reefs, it’s a non-factor.

Town vs outliers (winds and tides)
- Ala Moana (Bowls/Kaisers/Rockpiles):
  • Bowls: Best of the bunch for the S–SSW background, but still small. Cleanest at dawn with light ENE land breeze; trades turn it side-on and bumpy late morning onward. Mid tide helps the shape; very low tide makes it shallow and pinchy.
  • Kaisers/Rockpiles: Slightly better odds than Bowls to feel any W–NW wrap, but we’re talking marginal (<1 ft) Thu–Fri. If the late-Sat NNW 18s sets sneak in, expect long lulls and occasional knee-thigh lines—more novelty than session-maker.
- Waikiki: Most consistent option with the small S–SSW. Ideal for logs/SUPs. Handles trades better than the reefs, so afternoons can still be workable. Higher tides favor glide; very low tides expose the inside and shorten rides.
- Diamond Head: Limited exposure to the S–SSW source and no help from the NNW wrap. With trades, expect warble but rideable ramps early; best window is dawn before the breeze fills. Mainly knee–thigh, with occasional waist-high peaks on the better sets.

Boards, crowds, consistency
- Best craft: Longboards and mid-lengths rule; grovelly twins/fish for the reefs. Performance shortboards will feel undergunned except on the rare Bowls set.
- Consistency: Long waits—10 to 15 minutes between better pulses; even longer for any wrap set at the magnets.
- Crowds: Typical fall Town crowding focused on the few peaks showing push (Bowls at dawn, Canoes/Queens all day). Expect an uptick Saturday a.m. with weekend traffic despite no real size bump.

Local winds and quality
- Winds: Presently light ENE (~070° around 5–10 kt) at dawn, trending moderate trades by late morning through afternoons—side-onshore texture for most Town reefs. Diamond Head tolerates wind best; Waikiki is relatively sheltered. 
- Quality: Fair to fair–poor overall. Best surface conditions at first light; degrade to choppy/crumbly mid to late morning as the trades fill. Quality index around mid-pack (≈0.45) is a good reflection.

Notes on data and confidence
- Confidence is medium (0.68). Several feeds missing (altimetry, models, nearshore buoys), and one short-lived “SW 13s at 16 ft” buoy blip is almost certainly spurious/directional aliasing given regional charts and climatology. The call leans on functioning buoys, tides, METARs, and October norms. No tropical assistance expected.

Bottom line
- Thu–Sat stays small: mainly knee–waist with the odd chest-high set at focal Town reefs on the tide push. NW wrap is negligible for Town until a token, very long-period tease near sunset Saturday at the usual west-facing magnets. Dawn patrol with a log or fish is your highest-yield play.
daily:
HEADLINE: XL NNW dominates with still-solid SSW; light ENE trades early — expert-only north/west, select south reefs at dawn.

NORTH SHORE: 18–25+ ft faces on sets, NNW (320–340°) 14–15s energy. Best window dawn to mid-morning under light ENE side-off; strong, long-period sets and heavy currents. Outer reefs/Waimea on; most spots hazardous.

SOUTH SHORE: 5–8 ft faces, occasional 8–10+ at top SW magnets (205–220°) 12–14s; inconsistent but powerful sets. Best at first light before trades/sea-breeze texture; long lulls, backwash on higher tides.

EAST: Trade-wind exposures choppy and jumbled; wrap from NNW lights up select leeward corners but currents and sideshore winds limit quality.

WEST: 8–15+ ft faces from combined NNW and some SW wrap; cleaner under ENE offshore early. Heavy sweep and wide sets near channels; expert only at exposed reefs.

WINDS: ENE (070°) around 5–10 kt early, building moderate trades by late morning/afternoon. This is side-off to offshore for North and West (cleanest early), partial cross-off for South (manageable at dawn), onshore and bumpy for East.

TIDES (Honolulu 1612340; feed partial): 
- Trend: Low was near dusk Wed; rising overnight toward a late morning/near-midday high around 2 ft; falling again late afternoon to a very low near/after sunset (~0.2 ft). Verify exact times locally.
- Impacts: More push/backwash on late-morning highs south; stronger draw and exposed reefs on evening lows north/west.

HAZARDS: XL long-period NNW with still-solid SSW crossing — rogue sets, wide wrap, powerful rip currents, harbor surges, and shorebreak. Reefs washing through; cliff/rock splash zones dangerous.

ACTION ITEM: Experts with proper safety gear: go at first light on protected North/West reefs; Waimea/outer reefs only with team. Everyone else: pick the most sheltered South reefs right at dawn or stand down.

Tropical Weather Outlook
NWS Central Pacific Hurricane Center Honolulu HI
Issued by NWS National Hurricane Center Miami FL
800 PM HST Wed Oct 15 2025

For the central North Pacific...between 140W and 180W:

Tropical cyclone formation is not expected during the next 7 days.

$$
Forecaster Gibbs
